facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 405 of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 405 of 1971.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 17th 18th 1971 of Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 77 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 17th 18th 1971 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 77 of 1971.

facts.text: In elections to Vyara Taluka Panchayat in 1968, respondent No. 1 was elected as a member.

anchor.surface_text: In the elections to the Vyara Taluka Panchayat which took place in 1968 respondent No. 1 was elected as a member.

facts.text: At first meeting of Taluka Panchayat, respondent No. 1 elected as President.

anchor.surface_text: At the first meeting of the Taluka Panchayat he was elected as its President.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 became ex-officio member of Surat District Panchayat by virtue of S. 15(1)(a) of Gujarat Panchayats Act 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon he became ex-officio member of the Surat District Panchayat by virtue of S. 15 1  A  i  of the Gujarat Panchayats Act 1961, hereinafter called the Panchayats Act.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 elected as President of Surat District Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: He was ultimately elected as President of the Surat District Panchayat.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 ceased to hold office of President of Vyara Taluka Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: He ceased to hold his office of President of the Taluka Panchayat.

facts.text: Surat district consists of several Talukas including Chorashi Taluka with a Taluka Panchayat constituted under Panchayats Act.

anchor.surface_text: Surat district companysists of several Talukas one of such Talukas is called Chorashi Taluka for which a Taluka Panchayat was companystituted under the provisions of the Panchayats Act.

facts.text: Rander and Adajan were subject to authority of Surat District Panchayat and Chorashi Taluka Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: Two areas known as Rander and Adajan were subject to the authority of the Surat District Panchayat and the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat.

facts.text: Rander had a Nagar Panchayat and Adajan had a Gram Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: Rander had a Nagar Panchayat and Adajan had a Gram Panchayat.

facts.text: On January 16, 1970, notification issued by State Government under S. 3(3) of Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act 1949 including Rander and Adajan within limits of Surat Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1970 a numberification was issued by the State Government under S. 3  3  of the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations-Act 1949, to be referred to as the Corporations Act by-which the local areas of Rander and Adajan were included within the limits of the Surat Municipal Corporation.

facts.text: Notification dated January 21, 1970 under S. 9(2) of Panchayats Act declaring Rander ceases to be Nagar and Adajan ceases to be Gram with effect from February 1, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a numberification dated January 21, 1970 under S. 9 2  of the Panchayats Act declaring that the local area of Rander shall cease to be a Nagar and that oil Adajan shall cease to be a Gram with effect from February 1, 1970.

facts.text: Rander and Adajan excluded from limits of Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and Surat District Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: The net result was that Rander and Adajan stood excluded from he limits of the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat.

facts.text: Notification issued on June 13, 1963 by Development Commissioner under s.310A dissolving Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and Surat District Panchayat with effect from January 11, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification was issued on June 13, 1963 by the Development Commissioner in exercise of the powers companyferred on the State Government under s. 31O A  of the Panchayats Act and delegated to him dissolving the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat with effect from January 11, 1971

facts.text: Members of dissolved Panchayats to vacate offices and Panchayats to be reconstituted with specified members.

anchor.surface_text: with a direction that the members of the dissolved Panchayat shall vacate offices and that the Taluka and District Panchayats shall be reconstituted with members specified in clause 3 of the Order-read with Schedules 1 and

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 ceased to be ex-officio member of reconstituted Surat District Panchayat as he no longer held office as President of Vyara Taluka Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 having ceased to hold office as President of the Vyara Taluka Panchayat when he was elected as President of the Surat District Panchayat companyld number be an ex-officio member of the reconstituted Surat District Panchayat because he had ceased to be an ex-officio member as such.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was not an elected member nor appointed under s.310A(2)(b) of Panchayats Act for reconstituted Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: He was number an elected member of the Surat District Panchayat and was number appointed a member under s. 310A 2  b  of the, Panchayats Act.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 ceased to be member and President of Surat District Panchayat upon reconstitution.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, ceased to be a member of the Surat District Panchayat as reconstituted. This led to the cessation of his holding the office of the President of that Panchayat.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed petition under Art. 226 challenging validity of dissolution and reconstitution order.

anchor.surface_text: He filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the order of dissolution and reconstitution made by the Development Commissioner.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court held Development Commissioner had no power to dissolve under s.310A(1) due to s.310A(10).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided the first question against the State and held that by reason of the exception companytained in S. 310A 1O  of the Panchayats Act the Development Commissioner had numberpower to dissolve the Panchayat in question under sub-s.  1  of that section.

facts.text: Second ground of mala fides not decided by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The second point was number gone into as it was companysidered unnecessary to decide it.

facts.text: Gujarat Panchayats Act 1961 enacted to consolidate law relating to village panchayats and district local boards.

anchor.surface_text: This Act. according to the preamble, was enacted to companysolidate and amend the law relating to village panchayat and district local boards in the State of Gujarat etc.

facts.text: Section 310A introduced by Gujarat Act 26 of 1962, came into force August 18, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Section 310A did number exist in the Panchayats Act as enacted. It was subsequently introduced by Gujarat Act 26 of 1962 which came into force on August 18, 1962.

facts.text: Notification dated February 7, 1963 under s.1(3) brought s.310A into force in all districts except Dangs.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated February 7, 1963 under s. 1 3 , s. 310A was brought into force in all the districts of the State of Gujarat except the district of Dangs.

facts.text: Surat constituted as city with effect from October 1, 1966 under s.3(2) of Corporations Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Surat which was originally a municipal borough was companystituted a city with effect from October 1, 1966 by means of a numberification issued under s. 3 2  of the Corporations Act.

Section 279 2  of the aforesaid Act made the following provisions Notwithstanding the repeal of the said Acts,- any local area declared to be either a municipal borough or municipal district immediately before the date on which this Act comes into force  hereinafter referred to as the said date  shall be deemed to be a muni- cipal borough under this Act the municipalities constituted under the said Acts immediately before the said date  hereinafter called the old municipalities  shall be deemed to be municipalities of the respective boroughs  hereinafter respectively called the new municipalities and the new boroughs

issues.text: Whether the Development Commissioner as a delegate of the State Government had power to dissolve the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat under S. 310A(1) of the Panchayats Act by reason of the provisions contained in sub-s. (10) of that section.

anchor.surface_text: The first was that the Development Com- missioner as a delegate of the State Government had no power to dissolve the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat under S. 310A 1  of the Panchayat Act by reason of the provisions contained in sub-s.  10  of that section.

issues.text: Whether the order had been made by the Development Commissioner mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: The second point was that the order had been made by the Development Commissioner mala fide. The High Court decided the first question against the State

issues.text: Whether the applicability of s. 310A(10) would be attracted by virtue of s. 493 read with Appendix IV, Para 1 of the Corporations Act.

anchor.surface_text: This immediately led to the question whether the applicability of s. 310A 10 would be attracted by virtue of s. 493 read with Appendix IV, Para 1 of the Corporations Act.

issues.text: Whether the word 'district' in s. 1(3) of the Panchayats Act means a revenue district and not a district as defined in s. 2(6) of the Panchayats Act.

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the High Court appears to have been that the word district in s. 1 3 must me-an a revenue district and not a district as defined in s. 2 6  of the Panchayats Act.

issues.text: Whether there is a different intention appearing in s. 310A(10) and its Explanation that prevents the application of Appendix IV Para 1 of the Corporations Act.

holdings.text: The Development Commissioner as a delegate of the State Government had no power to dissolve the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat under S. 310A(1) of the Panchayats Act by reason of the provisions contained in sub-s. (10) of that section.

anchor.surface_text: The first was that the Development Com- missioner as a delegate of the State Government had no power to dissolve the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and the Surat District Panchayat under S. 310A 1  of the Panchayat Act by reason of the provisions contained in sub-s.  10  of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's interpretation that s.310A(10) exception applies via Corporations Act Appendix IV Para 1 construing 'municipal borough' as 'city'; no infirmity found after considering State contentions.

holdings.text: The applicability of s. 310A(10) is attracted by virtue of s. 493 read with Appendix IV, Para 1 of the Corporations Act, construing 'municipal borough' as 'City'.

anchor.surface_text: This immediately led to the question whether the applicability of s. 310A 10 would be attracted by virtue of s. 493 read with Appendix IV, Para 1 of the Corporations Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchayats Act including s.310A in force in revenue district encompassing Surat municipal borough prior to its constitution as city on Oct 1, 1966; Appendix IV Para 1 deems references to continue unless different intention.

holdings.text: The word 'district' in s. 1(3) of the Panchayats Act means a revenue district and not a district as defined in s. 2(6) of the Panchayats Act.

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the High Court appears to have been that the word district in s. 1 3 must me-an a revenue district and not a district as defined in s. 2 6  of the Panchayats Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical necessity as Panchayats Act district forms only after s.1(3) notification brings provisions into force; cannot notify in a district yet to exist under the Act.

holdings.text: No different intention appears in s. 310A(10) and its Explanation that prevents the application of Appendix IV Para 1 of the Corporations Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of 'city' in s.310A(10) and Explanation possibly because Appendix IV applicability assumed; no contrary intention as provisions ensure continuity; absurdity argument rejected as words apply to actual boroughs.

holdings.text: There is no infirmity in the judgment of the High Court warranting reversal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: State's arguments on district meaning, different intention, and absurdity rejected; High Court's reasoning on revenue district, Appendix IV application, and harmonious construction found sound.

anchor.surface_text: After fully companysidering the companytentions raised on behalf of the State we are number satisfied that there is any such infirmity in the judgment of the High Court which makes it erroneous or would justify our taking a different view.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld holding that the Development Commissioner had no power to dissolve the Chorashi Taluka Panchayat and Surat District Panchayat under S. 310A(1) of the Panchayats Act by reason of sub-s.(10)
